debts. While I firmly believe that there ought to be economic and vocational
implications in the education of every college girl, as of every college boy, 1 do
not believe that the primary reasons for sending either a girl or a boy to college
are vocational. To put great onphasis on loan funds, and on college as a financial
investment, would create a cultural atmosphere which would lead to disaster. If
the private institutions adopt this tactic, the spiritual elements in American
education will quickly be drained off into the state institutions and the former will
degenerate into trade schools pure and simple.
However, undoubtedly independent institutions are going to find themselves
forced to raise their fees to levels which make us shudder to contemplate. Whereas
today the total fees of a resident undergraduate in a good Independent college run
in the neighborhood of $2,000, it is my bet that within a decade such fees will
amount to at least $3,000, in terms of the present value of the dollar. In no other
way can independent colleges hold or secure adequate fac^ltiess 1 believe that even
at such levels there will be a considerable constituency for the independent
institutions. Mills, I regret to say, at $1900 is the most expensive college on the
Pacific Coast, and yet we operate, in terms of defensible admissions standards, only
eight miles from the University of California at Berkeley where the fees for a
Califoimian are negligible, the standards of admission high, and the faculty
academically superb.
All of our independent institutions are going to raise their fees drastically,
and will still find students. But won't they also be pricing themselves out of so
large a segment of the market that quantitative expansion would be folly?
